title: Andhra Pradesh
summary: Andhra Pradesh (English: /ˌɑːndrə prəˈdɛʃ/;[10] Telugu: [ãːndʱrʌ prʌdeːɕ] listen ) is a state in the south-eastern coastal region of India.[11] It is the seventh-largest state by area covering an area of 162,975 km2 (62,925 sq mi)[4] and tenth-most populous state with 49,386,799 inhabitants,[12][13] with the state capital being Amaravati.[14] It is bordered by Telangana to the north-west, Chhattisgarh to the north, Odisha to the north-east, Tamil Nadu to the south, Karnataka to the west and the Bay of Bengal to the east.[15] It has the second longest coastline in India after Gujarat, of about 974 km (605 mi).[16] Andhra Pradesh is the first state to be formed on a linguistic basis in India on 1 October 1953.[17] The state was once a major Buddhist pilgrimage site in the country and a Buddhist learning center which can be seen in many sites in the state in the form of ruins, chaityas and stupas[18][19] It is also known as the land of the world-famous diamond Koh-i-Noor and many other globally known diamonds due to their source in its Kollur Mine.[20] It is also known as the "rice bowl of India" for being a major producer of rice in India.[21] Its official language is Telugu; one of the classical languages of India, the fourth most spoken language in India and the 11th-most spoken language in the world.[22][23]
